title: Exercise topics to be discussed
content: In this AMA episode, Peter describes what it means to exercise with the goal of longevity in mind, including his personal goals, exercise framework, and how he is optimizing for what he refers to as the “Centenarian Decathlon.” He explains the various types of cardiovascular training and how to partition your time between intensity levels (i.e., zone 2 training vs. zone 5 training) to optimize cardiorespiratory benefit. Additionally, Peter dives deep into questions around VO2 max, such as why it’s critical for longevity, how to improve it, and the value in starting VO2 max optimization early in life.

title: Peter’s exercise goals, and the Centenarian Decathlon
content: Peter describes his personal goals for exercising with the goal of longevity in mind, including his framework for what he refers to as the “Centenarian Decathlon.”

content: Peter explains his exercise framework and how he tracks his MET hours.

title: How to partition your time between low and high intensity exercise to optimize results
content: Peter explains how to partition your time between low and high intensity exercise to optimize cardiorespiratory benefit.

content: Peter explains ideal training methods for Zone 2 exercise and how to determine your Zone 2 level.

content: Peter discusses rucking as a versatile mode of exercise.

content: Peter explains modalities of training, time per week, and other considerations for Zone 5 exercise.

content: Peter explains the importance of knowing your VO2 max and methods for estimating it.

content: Peter explains the value in starting early with fitness and the compounding nature of fitness.

title: Exercise topics to be discussed
content: Today will be some rapid fire questions going a little deeper on exercise topics. If all goes to plan we’ll cover all four pillars of questions that have come in. It should be a good well rounded AMA on all things exercise.

title: Peter’s exercise goals, and the Centenarian Decathlon
content: The Centenarian Decathlon is simply a mental model for how Peter thinks about training. In Peter’s long experience with training, something became very clear: Specificity matters. But people confuse specificity with narrow, that’s not the case. You can be broadly trained and broadly conditioned, but with specificity and focus—that’s really what the Centenarian Decathlon is all about. So it’s very difficult to be successful in a physical endeavor if you are not pursuing some sort of objective. And we’re going after a really hard problem—which is to be in the last decade of your life, what we call the marginal decade, and be incredibly robust physically. What does that look like to be physically robust in the marginal decade? Imagine a 90 year old who’s functioning like a 70 year old, but that is going to require a lot of preparation.

title: Training for Aging
content: When you think about the inevitability of decline of muscle mass, strength, cardiorespiratory fitness, you have to be training for that with the same degree of focus and specificity that a person is training for to be an exceptional athlete in their 30s or 40s. The Centenarian Decathlon basically forces us to be specific in what our metrics are in that last decade of life, and it allows us to “backcast” from there.

title: Peter's Exercise Framework
content: Today’s training is really focused on something different which are these 4 o 5 buckets: Zone 2, Zone 5, Strength, Stability, Rucking (“I include rucking in there because it is so physical…and the psychological benefit of it”).

title: Energy Expenditure
content: You can identify energy expenditure by how many METs are required for each activity. How much time you spend in each gives you MET hours per week. That’s probably the purest way to understand energy expenditure across those domains, says Peter.

title: Peter's MET Hours
content: Zone 2 is cycling for Peter — zone 2 is somewhere between 220 and 235 watts. You can use a calculator to tell you how many METs that is, so that’s 11 METs. If I spend four hours a week there, 11 x 4 = 44, so that’s 44 MET hours per week. Zone 5 is done by cycling or stair climbing, and that’s about 16 METs. Strength is lifting weights and that’s about an average of five METs but it depends greatly on what type of lifting being done. Rucking – Peter puts 55 or 60 lbs in his rucking pack. Total METs is about 100 MET hours per week of activity.

title: Partitioning Time for Exercise
content: What do we know about whether moderate intensity exercise is as good as vigorous intensity exercise? The reality is both are important. And Peter notes that he is now talking about this through the lens of assuming a person’s objectives are somewhat in line with his. This is a big assumption, which is do you want to be 84 years old and kind of able to do anything?

title: Combination of high and low intensity aerobic training, plus a lot of strength training
content: If what I just described is aspirationally, directionally where you want to be, you will need a combination of high and low intensity aerobic training, plus a lot of strength training.

title: Zone 2 vs Zone 5
content: Peter tells patient that basically 80 to 90% of their training volume from a cardio standpoint should be at zone 2, with the remainder being at zone 5. An age old adage that applies: “If you want to build a really big pyramid, you have to have a really wide base.” The base of the pyramid is your zone 2 capacity, the wider the base of your pyramid, the higher your zone 2 capacity. Your VO2 max, which is your maximum aerobic output, is the peak of the pyramid. If you want to have that high peak, if you want that massive engine, you have to have a huge base. 80/20 is kind of the rule of thumb, which is 80% of your time building the base, 20% shaping the peak. If your objective is to live longer and live healthier, you just can’t go wrong with an 80/20 split of zone 2 to zone 5.

title: Ideal training methods and how to determine your zone 2 level
content: Modes of zone 2: Peter says bike is his preference, however, treadmill is best for most people starting out. Rowing is a great exercise, but truthfully it’s quite technical. So if you don’t have the technique, you’re going to hurt yourself on a rowing machine for 45 minutes. Typically Peter would suggest if people have access to a treadmill, that’s the easiest way to go. The biggest impediment to zone 2 is that it’s much easier to do indoors than outdoors and therefore it’s nowhere near as enjoyable. Walking outdoors, generally, isn’t going to cut it because for most people you need some elevation change, meaning an increase, you need to be walking uphill to make it work. For a person who is just starting, the treadmill is probably the safest and easiest. Peter likes the bike the most because it has even less impact, but again, for some people they’re so inefficient in that position that it becomes counterproductive.

title: Beginner's Treadmill Pace
content: Generally have people get to the velocity that is going to be their maximum efficiency, and you’ll know you’re past that, when you feel like you want to start running. When you feel like to walk any faster, I might as well start running, that’s your maximum point. We don’t want you running just because of the impact—it’s 8:1 versus 3:1 application of body weight force to knee. Once you get to that maximum point, you increase the grade or elevation of the treadmill. We can do this off rate of perceived exertion (RPE), heart rate, and lactate.

title: Zone 2 Heart Rate
content: There’s the RPE test, and then there’s the heart rate guidance. Use heart rate as the boundary conditions, but ultimately until you get lactate tested, you’re probably going to have to rely on rate of perceived exertion. Heart rate guidance we provide people is triangulating between a couple of numbers. If a person doesn’t know anything, they don’t know what their maximum heart rate is, they’ve never done anything before, then Peter likes for them to use Phil Maffetone‘s guidance which is 180 minus your age (The MAF 180 Formula).

title: Zone 2 Threshold Changes with Conditioning
content: Basically, when you first start doing zone 2 consistently, you will see improvements in your efficiency and therefore your zone 2 threshold may be at a higher output of work. However, at some point you will plateau and the only way to meaningfully increase your efficiency is to add more and more volume of zone 2 work.

title: Rucking as a Versatile Mode of Exercise
content: In terms of what zone you are in while rucking, Peter says “it’s above and below and in.” For example, Peter is in zone 1 when on flat areas, he’s above zone 2 when walking on a hill, and when going downhill he’s probably zone 1. At the end of the ruck, his average HR might have been a 130 (therefore zone 1), but that exercise was anything but zone 1 — it’s more like interval training.

title: Importance of Staying in Zone 2
content: Importance of staying in zone 2 without interruption.

title: Zone 2 Exercise
content: If you go out for a four hour bike ride and your bike computer comes back and tells you spent one hour of that four in zone 2, that’s not the same as spending one hour straight in zone 2. There’s something about that form of exercise that requires staying in that zone and just letting the body crank through that metabolic pathway without interruption. Rucking on the treadmill is a fantastic way to get zone 2 and do so at a lower speed, frankly. If you’re challenged by speed or challenged by elevation, by all means put a little poundage on.

title: Zone 5 Exercise
content: Peter likes to do zone 5 on the stair climber. For the purposes of what we’re talking about, Peter likes to get people off the bike for at least some of what they’re doing, because life is basically handled off a bike. Therefore, I also think doing some of your zone 5 in that capacity as well, which again could be done on a treadmill with a ruck. Could be done with a ruck sack outdoors, if you can find a long enough hill or could be done on a stair machine. Peter recommends you do your zone 2 first and then your zone 5 on the same day. Zone 2 makes for a great warmup for your zone 5 (it’s hard to do zone 5 without a big warmup). Note: Peter’s zone 2 protocol is four days per week, and it’s 45 to 60 minutes depending on the day. Peter does zone 5 once per week on Saturday.

title: VO2 Max
content: The importance of knowing your VO2 max, and methods for estimating it. Gold standard is indirect calorimetry test. But just as with zone 2, there are other ways to estimate your VO2 max. If you have a really advanced sports watch, they’ll often have a feature on there that will sort of estimate your VO2 max based on how fast it thinks you’re moving, what your heart rate is, and then how much your heart rate recovers when you stop (not sure exactly how accurate these are). Running based tests are also common such as where you run a given distance and then take the time that you ran that distance in, multiply, divide it by something and that’ll give you a VO2 max. How fast you can run a mile, assuming you’re running it all out, can be used to predict your VO2 max. And those running based tests are reasonably accurate. Some of the machines (treadmill or a good stair climber) will tell you how many METs you’re working at. So they’ll tell you you’re at X many watts or  X METs and once you know how many METs you’re at, you can multiply that number by 3.5 and that tells you your VO2.

title: Methods to estimate your VO2 max
content: To estimate your VO2 max, you can use the Cooper method which involves running as far as you can in 12 minutes and measuring the distance covered in miles. Multiply the distance by 36 and subtract 11.3 to get an estimate of your VO2 max. It's important to do the test in an activity that you're comfortable with to avoid underestimating your capacity.

title: Training methods for improving VO2 max
content: The best way to train to increase VO2 max is through 4-6 minute intervals at a one to one ratio of rest to recovery. Peter typically prescribes four by four intervals for patients, where you do four minutes of high-intensity exercise followed by four minutes of rest, repeated 4-6 times. Longer interval training has also been shown to increase VO2 max, according to several studies.

title: Realistic targets for increase in VO2 max
content: Realistic targets for increasing VO2 max vary depending on the individual's starting point and training regimen. However, studies have shown that high-intensity interval training can increase VO2 max, and longer interval training has also been shown to be effective.

title: Boosting VO2 max
content: When trying to boost your VO2 max, you're trying to increase how many liters per minute of oxygen you can consume while minimizing your body weight. Peter likes to separate these metrics for people: how much can you increase in absolute amounts in the oxygen consumption in liters per minute and how much weight could you lose while doing that? The lower you start at, the more you can increase it. Mike Joyner talked about this in the podcast—he said you could get 10 to 20% of a VO2 max boost if you train specifically and consistently. The weight loss/fat loss component also can increase your VO2 max.

title: VO2 max and age
content: The relationship of VO2 max with age and the required cardiorespiratory fitness levels for daily life activities and exercise can be seen in Figure 3. The Y axis shows VO2 max, and the X axis shows age. The green curve shows a high fitness individual, the black curve shows somebody right in the middle of the bell curve, and the red curve shows the lowest level of fitness.

title: VO2 Max for Various Activities
content: This section shows the VO2 max required for various activities such as running at 10 miles per hour (57 VO2 max), running at 6 miles per hour (35 VO2 max), walking at 3 miles per hour on a flat surface (12 VO2 max), climbing stairs slowly (32 VO2 max), and going upstairs quickly (45 VO2 max).

title: Importance of VO2 Max for Physical Health
content: Peter Attia believes that maintaining a VO2 max above 32 mls per minute per kilogram is crucial for physical health. According to data, the average person exceeds that limit by the age of 50. People in the bottom 5% are already below that threshold even at the age of 25. Peter plans to live beyond 80 and wants to maintain an even higher VO2 max than the green line on the curve. He believes that having an elite VO2 max throughout life requires at least 75 MET hours per week of training.

title: Factors Contributing to VO2 Max Decline with Age
content: Three factors contribute to VO2 max: maximum heart rate, lean body mass, and cardiovascular training. Maximum heart rate declines with age, lean body mass decreases, and cardiovascular training becomes less effective. These factors explain why VO2 max decreases with age.

title: Training for Top 5% VO2 Max
content: The team analyzed studies and found that people achieving top 5% VO2 max train for 60 MET hours per week total. Peter believes it's hard to achieve this below 75 MET hours per week, considering other training for strength/stability.

title: The Compounding Nature of Fitness
content: Starting early is crucial in fitness due to its compounding nature. It's even more relevant than wealth accumulation. There is no lottery equivalent or inheritance of money in fitness. Time, intensity, and specificity are necessary components to be physically active in the final decade of life.
